about.title: About Elekti
about.methodologyText: Elekti uses a comprehensive, evidence-based approach to match your political views with South African political parties. Our system is designed to be fair, transparent, and non-partisan.
about.howItWorksText: You answer 41 carefully crafted questions covering major policy areas including healthcare, education, economy, governance, and social issues. Each question is designed to reveal your political preferences without bias toward any party.
about.scoringText: Each answer you provide is matched against documented party positions from official manifestos, policy documents, and public statements. Parties receive weighted scores based on how closely their stated positions align with your responses. We use a per-party normalization algorithm, meaning each party is scored against its own best possible match for the questions you answered. This ensures fair treatment for both moderate and radical parties. These scores are normalized on a 0-100 scale, with your top match and alternatives clearly identified. We also provide a confidence rating to help you understand how strong your match is.
about.transparencyText: All party positions and scoring weights are determined through rigorous research of official party documents. Our methodology is open and reviewable. We do not favor any political party or ideology - our sole purpose is to help you make informed decisions based on your values and the parties' stated positions.
about.dataSourcesText: Party positions are meticulously researched from official party manifestos, policy documents, parliamentary voting records, and verified public statements. We update our data regularly to reflect policy changes. All source materials are from official party channels or reputable news organisations. If you believe any information is inaccurate, we welcome corrections with proper documentation.
about.privacyText: Your privacy is absolutely paramount. We believe your political views are deeply personal and deserve the highest level of protection.
about.noTrackingText: We do not use cookies, analytics pixels, or any tracking technologies. We cannot see your answers, cannot identify you, and have no interest in doing so. Your quiz responses are never transmitted to our servers.
about.localOnlyText: Everything happens in your browser. Your answers are stored only on your device and nowhere else. If you clear your browser data, your results are gone forever - we have no backup because we never had them in the first place.
about.sharingText: When you share results, your answers are encoded directly into the URL link itself. This means anyone with that link can see your results, but the data never touches our servers. You control who sees your results by controlling who gets that link. Delete the link, and your results are truly private again.
about.analyticsText: We use Cloudflare Web Analytics, a privacy-first analytics service that does not use cookies, does not track individuals across websites, and does not collect any personally identifiable information. It provides us with basic aggregated statistics (like total page views) to help us understand if the site is being used, without compromising your privacy. Cloudflare cannot see your quiz answers or identify you personally.
about.partiesText: We include 11 major South African political parties representing diverse viewpoints across the political spectrum. Our selection is based on parliamentary representation, electoral significance, and ideological diversity.
about.disclaimerText: Elekti is an educational tool, not a substitute for research. Political parties are complex organisations with nuanced positions that evolve over time. We strongly encourage you to read party manifestos, attend public forums, and verify our information independently. This tool shows alignment based on stated positions - actual governance may differ. Use these results as a starting point for deeper exploration, not as your final decision.
about.viewDataText: In the spirit of complete transparency, you can inspect our raw data files yourself. These JSON files contain all party positions, scoring weights, and question metadata used by our algorithm.

anc.desc: The African National Congress is South Africa's governing party, advocating for social democracy, transformation, and addressing inequality through state intervention.

da.desc: The Democratic Alliance promotes liberal democracy, free market economics, and non-racial politics with emphasis on good governance and job creation.

mk.desc: uMkhonto we Sizwe Party focuses on radical economic transformation, advocating for state-led development and addressing historical injustices.

eff.desc: The Economic Freedom Fighters is a far-left party advocating for radical economic transformation, nationalization, and land redistribution without compensation.

ifp.desc: The Inkatha Freedom Party primarily represents Zulu communities, promoting Zulu cultural values, federalism, and free market economics with social responsibility. While it has broader appeal, policy priorities center on Zulu traditions and KwaZulu-Natal interests.

pa.desc: The Patriotic Alliance focuses on addressing immigration issues, promoting South African nationalism, and prioritising citizens' needs.

vfplus.desc: Freedom Front Plus primarily represents Afrikaner communities and interests, advocating for federalism, minority rights, and conservative values. Policy priorities center on Afrikaner cultural preservation and self-determination.

actionsa.desc: ActionSA is a centrist party focused on practical governance, anti-corruption, and economic growth through private sector engagement.

acdp.desc: The African Christian Democratic Party promotes Christian values, conservative social policies, and constitutional democracy.

ufc.desc: Unite for Change focuses on grassroots mobilization and addressing local community concerns through progressive policies.

sacp.desc: The South African Communist Party advocates for socialism, workers' rights, and the transition to a socialist society through state control.

q1.text: The government should raise taxes on the wealthy to fund expanded social programmes (health, education, social grants).

q2.text: Fiscal discipline and reducing public debt should be prioritised even if it limits new social spending.

q3.text: The government should actively support small and medium businesses with tax breaks and deregulation to spur growth.

q4.text: The state should introduce a universal basic income as a national policy.

q5.text: Public investment in job-rich public works programmes is a suitable short-term method to reduce unemployment.

q6.text: Healthcare should be universally publicly funded (basic services free at point of use).

q7.text: Higher education should be free for all students, even if it requires higher taxes.

q8.text: The state should provide strong subsidies for childcare to support working parents.

q9.text: Local government should be professionally staffed and independently audited to address chronic municipal failures and reduce corruption, even if this limits political appointments or triggers national intervention.

q10.text: Key public utilities (power, water, rail) should remain publicly owned and not be privatised.

q11.text: Expropriation of land without market-rate compensation should be allowed to speed up land reform.

q12.text: Smallholder farming and communal land rights should receive priority policy support over large commercial agribusiness.

q13.text: Workers should have stronger rights to unionise and strike, with fewer restrictions.

q14.text: Minimum wages should be increased significantly to reduce in-work poverty, even if some small businesses struggle.

q15.text: Labour market flexibility (easier hiring and firing) will increase investment and should be encouraged.

q16.text: Police should be given stronger powers and resources to tackle violent crime, even if it expands state authority.

q17.text: Independent oversight institutions (judiciary, prosecution) should be protected even if it slows prosecutions of powerful officials.

q18.text: Corruption prosecutions should be fast and aggressive even if they cause short-term instability in government.

q19.text: Civil liberties such as freedom of expression and peaceful protest should be prioritised even when demonstrations disrupt traffic or economic activity and complicate policing operations.

q20.text: The state should actively promote LGBTQ+ anti-discrimination protections and inclusion policies.

q21.text: South Africa should set legally binding national targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions and phase out coal power over time.

q22.text: The state should prioritise investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency to reduce dependence on Eskom/coal.

q23.text: Environmental protection laws should take priority over new mineral and coal developments.

q24.text: South Africa should prioritise export-led growth through stronger trade links with international markets.

q25.text: South Africa should prioritise building stronger strategic ties with other Global South countries over exclusive alignment with Western powers.

q26.text: Trade policy should prioritise protecting local industries through tariffs and local content rules.

q27.text: Public funds for transport infrastructure should prioritise mass public transit (rail and BRT) over new highway construction, including major expansions in Gauteng, even if this inconveniences motorists or slows growth in car-dependent areas.

q28.text: Affordable public housing projects should be prioritised over incentives for private housing developers.

q29.text: Cities should be required by law to restrict new low-density, car-dependent developments and enforce zoning rules that mandate walkable, mixed-use neighborhoodsâ€”even if this limits private property rights or increases housing costs.

q30.text: South Africa should adopt strong digital privacy laws limiting corporate and state surveillance.

q31.text: Food security should be achieved through a national strategy supporting local production, agroecology and community gardens.

q32.text: Government departments should be legally required to meet strict accessibility standards for people with disabilities, even if this means diverting funds from other public services or increasing regulatory burdens.

q33.text: The state should introduce targeted subsidies and incentives to accelerate township and rural economies.

q34.text: South Africa should adopt significantly stricter immigration and border enforcement policies, even if this strains relations with neighbouring countries or reduces labour supply in certain sectors.

q35.text: Government should more aggressively regulate the employment of undocumented foreign nationals, even if this disrupts industries that rely on migrant labour.

q36.text: Political parties should compromise on their ideological positions to form stable coalition governments, even if this disappoints some supporters.

q37.text: Policies such as Employment Equity and BEE should remain central tools for addressing racial inequality, even if they limit flexibility for businesses.

q38.text: Private companies should be allowed to generate and sell electricity widely to end load-shedding, even if this reduces Eskom's central role in the energy sector.

q39.text: National government should intervene more aggressively in failing municipalities, even if this limits local democratic autonomy.

q40.text: Disruptive protests and shutdowns should face stronger legal limits, even if this restricts certain forms of political expression.

q41.text: Political leaders who publicly undermine the judiciary, electoral bodies, or the Constitution should face formal consequences, even if their statements are framed as political speech.
